conclusion: U-shaped tube with unequal diameters, tube A is open upward, tube B is closed, cross-sectional area of tube B is 3 times that of tube A, filled with mercury, atmospheric pressure is 76 cmHg, ambient temperature is 27°C, distance from mercury surface in tube A to opening is 24 cm, mercury surface is 4 cm higher than in tube B, length of air column in tube B is 12 cm, a piston seals tube A, gas in A is heated while B remains at constant temperature.
Pressure at the mercury surface in tube A is atmospheric pressure, 76 cmHg.
Pressure in tube B is 80 cmHg due to mercury in A being 4 cm higher than in B.
Initial volume of gas in tube A is 24A cm³.
Initial volume of gas in tube B is 36A cm³.
Using ideal gas law for tube A: 76 x 24A = n_A R x 300.
Using ideal gas law for tube B: 80 x 36A = n_B R x 300.
When liquid levels equalize, mercury in tube A goes down by 3 cm, and mercury in tube B goes up by 1 cm.
Final volume in tube A is 27A cm³.
Final pressure in tube A is 76 cmHg.
Final volume in tube B is 33A cm³.
Final pressure in tube B is 76 cmHg.
Using ideal gas law and conservation of amount of gas in tube A: 76 x 24A / 300 = 76 x 27A / T_A2.
Converting 337.5 K to Celsius gives approximately 64.4°C.
The temperature of the gas in tube A when the liquid levels in both tubes are equal is approximately 64.4°C.
